--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> We don't have to represent suits because they have no
> role in concentration.  

Well, they could, if you are using a standard deck and, for example, 
only red or black pairs could be matched (there are lots of different 
variations that might be interesting to implement).

> Let's say we use the six card deck describe above. 
> For each of the six positions we have 5 binary inputs.
> One input is for whether there is a card there or not.
> Another if or whether the card is face down or now.
> If there is a card and its face up, then the other
> three inputs are for its identity, 1, 2 or 3.

So in this case, your net has 30 input nodes?  Just thinking back to 
our discussion of Darren Izzard's shape recognizer, and possible ways 
to input board states of games like Tic-Tac-Toe, it might be more 
efficient to only have two sets of inputs, in this case 10 inputs, 
only for the cards being "looked at" each turn.

Perhaps you could have the outputs be the X and Y coordinates of the 
next two choices, and those outputs could have connections that feed 
directly back into the input of the net (it might be very interesting 
to start without these connections and see if and/or how long it 
takes for them to develop).

This would probably be a more efficient representation, since the net 
would only look at two positions each turn, instead of looking at 
every position each turn. 

> I could reduce the number of inputs to three by using
> binary coding: 000 no card, 111 face down, 001 ace,
> 010 deuce, 100 trey.  I would like to hear opinions
> about whether that's a good idea.  If this works it
> makes it easier to enlarge the deck.

My instinct would be to not combine the nodes that identify the cards 
with the ones that indicate its up/down state, but I'm admittedly not 
very experienced.  I'd probably have a dedicated node that indicates 
card state, and have separate input nodes for the identity.

Anybody else have any thoughts on this?

> > If your inputs range from 0 to 1, are you
> > representing
> > each type of card as a value range (e.g. King/clubs
> > is
> > from 0 to 0.33, 2/hearts is from .33 to .66, etc.)?
> 
> Ken thought it was not a good idea to use this
> representation, and I'm inclined to agree.

Yeah, I would too. :)

Derek
